active_tasks.title: Distribute New Extension
steps: Verify the new extension package is ready and tested
Prepare distribution list of all team members and students who need the extension
Create clear installation instructions document with screenshots
Send out distribution email or notification with download link and installation guide
Monitor installation confirmations and track who has successfully installed
Provide technical support for any installation issues that arise
Follow up with individuals who haven't confirmed installation by end of day
Document any bugs or issues reported during initial deployment
resources: Extension package file location in shared drive
Previous extension distribution emails for template reference
active_tasks.instructions: Before distribution, ensure the extension has been thoroughly tested in a sandbox environment. Prepare a comprehensive email that includes: download link, step-by-step installation instructions with visual aids, expected features and improvements, troubleshooting section for common issues, and contact information for support. Send the distribution email to all recipients on your prepared list. Set up a tracking spreadsheet to monitor who has downloaded, installed, and confirmed successful operation. Be available throughout the morning to respond immediately to any technical difficulties. Schedule follow-up communications for those who haven't responded within 2-3 hours. Collect feedback on the new extension's functionality and user experience for future improvements.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Verify the new extension package is ready and tested
Prepare distribution list of all team members and students who need the extension
Create clear installation instructions document with screenshots
Send out distribution email or notification with download link and installation guide
Monitor installation confirmations and track who has successfully installed
Provide technical support for any installation issues that arise
Follow up with individuals who haven't confirmed installation by end of day
Document any bugs or issues reported during initial deployment

**Resources:**
- Extension package file location in shared drive
- Previous extension distribution emails for template reference
- Technical support documentation
- Installation troubleshooting guide
- User feedback collection form

**Instructions:**
Before distribution, ensure the extension has been thoroughly tested in a sandbox environment. Prepare a comprehensive email that includes: download link, step-by-step installation instructions with visual aids, expected features and improvements, troubleshooting section for common issues, and contact information for support. Send the distribution email to all recipients on your prepared list. Set up a tracking spreadsheet to monitor who has downloaded, installed, and confirmed successful operation. Be available throughout the morning to respond immediately to any technical difficulties. Schedule follow-up communications for those who haven't responded within 2-3 hours. Collect feedback on the new extension's functionality and user experience for future improvements.

active_tasks.title: Review Recent Broadcasts/Streams
steps: Access the platform where broadcasts/streams are hosted
Identify all streams from the past week that need review
Watch each broadcast, taking detailed notes on content, delivery, and engagement
Note timestamps for important moments or issues
Assess student participation and interaction during live sessions
Identify any technical difficulties or quality issues
Document key teaching points and topics covered
Create summary report of findings and recommendations
Share insights with relevant team members
resources: Team communication channel for sharing insights
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by creating a structured review template that includes: broadcast date/time, topic covered, presenter name, technical quality assessment, content effectiveness, student engagement level, questions asked, issues encountered, and follow-up actions needed. Watch each broadcast at 1.5x speed if time is limited, but slow down for critical sections. Take screenshots of important slides or moments for reference. Pay special attention to student questions in the chat or comments as these indicate areas of confusion or high interest. Note any technical glitches (audio issues, connection drops, screen sharing problems) with timestamps. Evaluate presenter effectiveness including clarity, pacing, energy level, and ability to engage the audience. Create actionable recommendations for improving future broadcasts. Compile all notes into a comprehensive review document and share with the team along with specific suggestions for improvement.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Access the platform where broadcasts/streams are hosted
Identify all streams from the past week that need review
Watch each broadcast, taking detailed notes on content, delivery, and engagement
Note timestamps for important moments or issues
Assess student participation and interaction during live sessions
Identify any technical difficulties or quality issues
Document key teaching points and topics covered
Create summary report of findings and recommendations
Share insights with relevant team members

**Resources:**
- Streaming platform login credentials
- Previous broadcast review templates
- Student engagement metrics dashboard
- Content quality checklist
- Team communication channel for sharing insights

**Instructions:**
Begin by creating a structured review template that includes: broadcast date/time, topic covered, presenter name, technical quality assessment, content effectiveness, student engagement level, questions asked, issues encountered, and follow-up actions needed. Watch each broadcast at 1.5x speed if time is limited, but slow down for critical sections. Take screenshots of important slides or moments for reference. Pay special attention to student questions in the chat or comments as these indicate areas of confusion or high interest. Note any technical glitches (audio issues, connection drops, screen sharing problems) with timestamps. Evaluate presenter effectiveness including clarity, pacing, energy level, and ability to engage the audience. Create actionable recommendations for improving future broadcasts. Compile all notes into a comprehensive review document and share with the team along with specific suggestions for improvement.

active_tasks.title: Check New Student Cards and Identify Issues
steps: Access the student management system or database
Filter for newly enrolled students (past 1-2 weeks)
Review each student's profile card systematically
Check attendance records for concerning patterns
Review assignment submission rates and grades
Examine engagement metrics (logins, activity, participation)
Identify red flags: missed deadlines, low engagement, declining grades, no communication
Categorize issues by type: technical, academic, motivation, personal
Create prioritized intervention list
Document specific concerns for each at-risk student
Prepare personalized outreach messages
Schedule follow-up check-ins
resources: Communication templates for different issue types
Counseling or academic support referral process
active_tasks.instructions: Start by establishing clear criteria for identifying students who need support. Red flags include: missing more than 2 consecutive sessions, assignment completion rate below 70%, no forum or chat participation for 5+ days, declining grade trend, or direct communication expressing difficulty. For each new student, review their complete profile including enrollment date, program/course, attendance history, assignment grades, participation metrics, communication history, and any notes from other team members. Create a color-coded spreadsheet with student names and issue severity (green=on track, yellow=minor concerns, red=immediate intervention needed). For each at-risk student, document specific issues observed with data to support your assessment. Develop individualized intervention plans that might include: one-on-one meeting, peer mentoring, additional resources, deadline extensions, or referral to academic support. Prepare personalized outreach messages that are empathetic, specific about concerns, offer concrete support, and invite open communication. Prioritize reaching out to "red flag" students first, ideally by early afternoon, to show immediate support and prevent further disengagement.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Access the student management system or database
Filter for newly enrolled students (past 1-2 weeks)
Review each student's profile card systematically
Check attendance records for concerning patterns
Review assignment submission rates and grades
Examine engagement metrics (logins, activity, participation)
Identify red flags: missed deadlines, low engagement, declining grades, no communication
Categorize issues by type: technical, academic, motivation, personal
Create prioritized intervention list
Document specific concerns for each at-risk student
Prepare personalized outreach messages
Schedule follow-up check-ins

**Resources:**
- Student management system/CRM access
- Student profile card template
- Engagement metrics dashboard
- Intervention strategy guidelines
- Communication templates for different issue types
- Counseling or academic support referral process

**Instructions:**
Start by establishing clear criteria for identifying students who need support. Red flags include: missing more than 2 consecutive sessions, assignment completion rate below 70%, no forum or chat participation for 5+ days, declining grade trend, or direct communication expressing difficulty. For each new student, review their complete profile including enrollment date, program/course, attendance history, assignment grades, participation metrics, communication history, and any notes from other team members. Create a color-coded spreadsheet with student names and issue severity (green=on track, yellow=minor concerns, red=immediate intervention needed). For each at-risk student, document specific issues observed with data to support your assessment. Develop individualized intervention plans that might include: one-on-one meeting, peer mentoring, additional resources, deadline extensions, or referral to academic support. Prepare personalized outreach messages that are empathetic, specific about concerns, offer concrete support, and invite open communication. Prioritize reaching out to "red flag" students first, ideally by early afternoon, to show immediate support and prevent further disengagement.

active_tasks.title: LinkedIn Activity Review
steps: Log into LinkedIn account
Review notification center for all new activity
Check connection requests and evaluate each one
Review messages and respond to pending inquiries
Read through feed for industry news and relevant posts
Engage with posts from connections (like, comment, share)
Check your profile for needed updates
Review company/organization pages you follow for news
Identify networking opportunities or events
Post update if relevant content is available
active_tasks.instructions: Begin with a systematic review of all notifications including profile views, post engagements, connection requests, and messages. For connection requests, evaluate each person's profile to ensure they align with your professional network goals (industry relevance, mutual connections, professional background). Accept appropriate requests and send personalized thank you messages. Review all unread messages and prioritize responses based on urgency and importance. Spend time scrolling through your feed and engage authentically with at least 5-10 posts from your network through thoughtful comments, not just likes. Look for industry trends, job postings, or educational resources that might benefit your team or students. Share valuable content with your network, adding your own insights or commentary to increase engagement. Update your profile if any accomplishments, skills, or experience changes need to be reflected. Check relevant groups or forums for discussions where you can contribute expertise. Identify any upcoming virtual events, webinars, or networking opportunities that align with professional development goals. If you have valuable insights, create a post to share with your network (could be about education trends, student success stories, industry news, or professional tips).
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Log into LinkedIn account
Review notification center for all new activity
Check connection requests and evaluate each one
Review messages and respond to pending inquiries
Read through feed for industry news and relevant posts
Engage with posts from connections (like, comment, share)
Check your profile for needed updates
Review company/organization pages you follow for news
Identify networking opportunities or events
Post update if relevant content is available

**Resources:**
- LinkedIn profile
- Content calendar for posts
- Industry news sources for sharing
- Professional development resources
- Networking strategy document

**Instructions:**
Begin with a systematic review of all notifications including profile views, post engagements, connection requests, and messages. For connection requests, evaluate each person's profile to ensure they align with your professional network goals (industry relevance, mutual connections, professional background). Accept appropriate requests and send personalized thank you messages. Review all unread messages and prioritize responses based on urgency and importance. Spend time scrolling through your feed and engage authentically with at least 5-10 posts from your network through thoughtful comments, not just likes. Look for industry trends, job postings, or educational resources that might benefit your team or students. Share valuable content with your network, adding your own insights or commentary to increase engagement. Update your profile if any accomplishments, skills, or experience changes need to be reflected. Check relevant groups or forums for discussions where you can contribute expertise. Identify any upcoming virtual events, webinars, or networking opportunities that align with professional development goals. If you have valuable insights, create a post to share with your network (could be about education trends, student success stories, industry news, or professional tips).

active_tasks.title: Review and Respond to Messages
steps: Consolidate all communication channels in one view
Check email inbox and sort by priority/urgency
Review messaging platform (Slack, Teams, etc.) for unread messages
Check LinkedIn messages (covered in Task 4)
Review any SMS or other communication channels
Categorize messages: urgent, important, routine, FYI
Respond to all urgent messages immediately
Draft responses to important messages
Schedule time blocks for routine responses
Archive or file completed conversations
Set reminders for follow-ups needed
Update task list if messages create new action items
active_tasks.instructions: Start by checking all communication channels and creating a master list of unread/pending messages with priority levels. Use the Eisenhower Matrix to categorize: Urgent & Important (respond immediately), Important but Not Urgent (schedule response within 24 hours), Urgent but Not Important (delegate or quick response), Neither Urgent nor Important (batch process or archive). For urgent messages requiring immediate attention, respond within 30 minutes with either a full answer or acknowledgment that you're working on it with expected response time. For important messages, draft thoughtful, complete responses that address all questions or concerns raised. Use templates for common inquiries to save time, but personalize each message. Keep responses clear, concise, and action-oriented with specific next steps or timelines. If a message requires significant time to address properly, send a quick acknowledgment and schedule dedicated time to provide a comprehensive response. Set up email filters and labels to automatically organize incoming messages. Use the two-minute rule: if a response takes less than two minutes, do it immediately rather than adding to your task list. For messages that generate new tasks, immediately add them to your action item list with appropriate priority and deadline. End the day with inbox zero or a clearly organized inbox where all messages are categorized and have scheduled response times.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Consolidate all communication channels in one view
Check email inbox and sort by priority/urgency
Review messaging platform (Slack, Teams, etc.) for unread messages
Check LinkedIn messages (covered in Task 4)
Review any SMS or other communication channels
Categorize messages: urgent, important, routine, FYI
Respond to all urgent messages immediately
Draft responses to important messages
Schedule time blocks for routine responses
Archive or file completed conversations
Set reminders for follow-ups needed
Update task list if messages create new action items

**Resources:**
- Email client
- Team messaging platform
- Communication response templates
- Priority matrix for message triage
- Calendar for scheduling follow-ups

**Instructions:**
Start by checking all communication channels and creating a master list of unread/pending messages with priority levels. Use the Eisenhower Matrix to categorize: Urgent & Important (respond immediately), Important but Not Urgent (schedule response within 24 hours), Urgent but Not Important (delegate or quick response), Neither Urgent nor Important (batch process or archive). For urgent messages requiring immediate attention, respond within 30 minutes with either a full answer or acknowledgment that you're working on it with expected response time. For important messages, draft thoughtful, complete responses that address all questions or concerns raised. Use templates for common inquiries to save time, but personalize each message. Keep responses clear, concise, and action-oriented with specific next steps or timelines. If a message requires significant time to address properly, send a quick acknowledgment and schedule dedicated time to provide a comprehensive response. Set up email filters and labels to automatically organize incoming messages. Use the two-minute rule: if a response takes less than two minutes, do it immediately rather than adding to your task list. For messages that generate new tasks, immediately add them to your action item list with appropriate priority and deadline. End the day with inbox zero or a clearly organized inbox where all messages are categorized and have scheduled response times.

active_tasks.title: Support with Dropbox Themes/Issues
steps: Check support request queue for Dropbox-related issues
Review existing Dropbox organization structure
Identify common problems or recurring themes
Triage issues by severity and impact
Respond to individual support requests with solutions
Create or update documentation for common issues
Test solutions before implementing for users
Provide step-by-step guidance to affected users
Follow up to confirm issues are resolved
Document lessons learned and update knowledge base
Identify systemic issues that need permanent fixes
Implement preventive measures for future problems
resources: Troubleshooting guide for common Dropbox issues
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by reviewing all reported Dropbox issues and categorizing them by type: access/permissions problems, file organization/structure issues, sync problems, storage limitations, sharing difficulties, version control confusion, or missing files. For each issue, gather complete information including: who is affected, what they're trying to do, what error they're seeing, when the problem started, and what troubleshooting they've already attempted. Prioritize issues that affect multiple users or block critical work. For access and permissions issues, verify user roles in the admin panel and adjust sharing settings appropriately while maintaining security protocols. For organizational issues, provide clear guidance on the established folder structure and naming conventions, helping users relocate misplaced files. Create visual guides with screenshots showing the correct file structure and how to navigate it effectively. For sync issues, walk users through the standard troubleshooting steps: checking internet connection, restarting Dropbox app, checking selective sync settings, verifying storage space, and clearing cache if needed. Document each issue and its solution in a knowledge base so future similar problems can be resolved quickly. If you identify recurring issues, develop permanent solutions such as improved folder templates, clearer naming conventions, automated organization scripts, or better onboarding documentation. Proactively communicate best practices to prevent issues, such as regular file organization tips, storage management guidance, and effective collaboration workflows. Follow up with each person who reported an issue within 24 hours to confirm resolution and gather feedback on the support process.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Check support request queue for Dropbox-related issues
Review existing Dropbox organization structure
Identify common problems or recurring themes
Triage issues by severity and impact
Respond to individual support requests with solutions
Create or update documentation for common issues
Test solutions before implementing for users
Provide step-by-step guidance to affected users
Follow up to confirm issues are resolved
Document lessons learned and update knowledge base
Identify systemic issues that need permanent fixes
Implement preventive measures for future problems

**Resources:**
- Dropbox admin panel
- File organization standards document
- Troubleshooting guide for common Dropbox issues
- User permissions matrix
- Backup and recovery procedures
- Knowledge base/FAQ document

**Instructions:**
Begin by reviewing all reported Dropbox issues and categorizing them by type: access/permissions problems, file organization/structure issues, sync problems, storage limitations, sharing difficulties, version control confusion, or missing files. For each issue, gather complete information including: who is affected, what they're trying to do, what error they're seeing, when the problem started, and what troubleshooting they've already attempted. Prioritize issues that affect multiple users or block critical work. For access and permissions issues, verify user roles in the admin panel and adjust sharing settings appropriately while maintaining security protocols. For organizational issues, provide clear guidance on the established folder structure and naming conventions, helping users relocate misplaced files. Create visual guides with screenshots showing the correct file structure and how to navigate it effectively. For sync issues, walk users through the standard troubleshooting steps: checking internet connection, restarting Dropbox app, checking selective sync settings, verifying storage space, and clearing cache if needed. Document each issue and its solution in a knowledge base so future similar problems can be resolved quickly. If you identify recurring issues, develop permanent solutions such as improved folder templates, clearer naming conventions, automated organization scripts, or better onboarding documentation. Proactively communicate best practices to prevent issues, such as regular file organization tips, storage management guidance, and effective collaboration workflows. Follow up with each person who reported an issue within 24 hours to confirm resolution and gather feedback on the support process.

active_tasks.title: Rewrite Templates for Old Connections
steps: Review current templates being used for old connections
Analyze response rates and effectiveness of existing templates
Research best practices for re-engagement messaging
Identify different categories of old connections (dormant clients, past colleagues, inactive students, etc.)
Create customized templates for each category
Incorporate personalization variables
Draft subject lines that increase open rates
Write compelling body content that provides value
Include clear call-to-action
Test templates with small sample group
Gather feedback and refine
Create template library with usage guidelines
Document when and how to use each template
resources: Analytics on previous outreach campaign performance
A/B testing results from previous campaigns
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by auditing all existing templates used for reconnecting with old connections. Analyze their performance metrics including open rates, response rates, and conversion rates to identify what's working and what isn't. Review the language, tone, length, and structure of current templates. Research current best practices for re-engagement communication, focusing on personalization, value-driven content, and authentic relationship building. Segment your old connections into meaningful categories such as: former clients/customers, past professional colleagues, dormant network connections, alumni, inactive students or program participants, and cold leads who showed initial interest. For each category, create 2-3 template variations that can be personalized based on specific circumstances. Key elements for effective reconnection templates include: personalized opening that references specific shared history or connection point, acknowledgment of time passed without being apologetic, genuine reason for reaching out (not just "checking in"), value proposition or offering (helpful resource, relevant opportunity, interesting information), open-ended question to encourage response, and clear but low-pressure call-to-action. Subject lines should be concise, personal, and intriguing without being clickbait (examples: "Quick question about [specific topic]", "Thought of you when I saw [relevant news]", "[Shared connection] suggested I reach out"). Keep email body concise (150-250 words maximum), focus on the recipient's interests rather than your agenda, and make it easy to respond with a simple yes/no or short answer question. Include personalization variables such as [First Name], [Company], [Last Interaction Date], [Shared Interest/Project], [Mutual Connection] that must be filled in for each message. Create usage guidelines that specify which template to use in which scenario, how much to customize beyond the template, optimal timing for sending, and appropriate follow-up sequences. Test new templates with a small sample of each connection category, measure results, gather any direct feedback, and refine based on data. Organize final templates in an easily accessible library with clear labeling and instructions for use.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Review current templates being used for old connections
Analyze response rates and effectiveness of existing templates
Research best practices for re-engagement messaging
Identify different categories of old connections (dormant clients, past colleagues, inactive students, etc.)
Create customized templates for each category
Incorporate personalization variables
Draft subject lines that increase open rates
Write compelling body content that provides value
Include clear call-to-action
Test templates with small sample group
Gather feedback and refine
Create template library with usage guidelines
Document when and how to use each template

**Resources:**
- Current template repository
- Analytics on previous outreach campaign performance
- Email marketing best practices guides
- CRM system for connection history
- A/B testing results from previous campaigns
- Professional copywriting resources

**Instructions:**
Begin by auditing all existing templates used for reconnecting with old connections. Analyze their performance metrics including open rates, response rates, and conversion rates to identify what's working and what isn't. Review the language, tone, length, and structure of current templates. Research current best practices for re-engagement communication, focusing on personalization, value-driven content, and authentic relationship building. Segment your old connections into meaningful categories such as: former clients/customers, past professional colleagues, dormant network connections, alumni, inactive students or program participants, and cold leads who showed initial interest. For each category, create 2-3 template variations that can be personalized based on specific circumstances. Key elements for effective reconnection templates include: personalized opening that references specific shared history or connection point, acknowledgment of time passed without being apologetic, genuine reason for reaching out (not just "checking in"), value proposition or offering (helpful resource, relevant opportunity, interesting information), open-ended question to encourage response, and clear but low-pressure call-to-action. Subject lines should be concise, personal, and intriguing without being clickbait (examples: "Quick question about [specific topic]", "Thought of you when I saw [relevant news]", "[Shared connection] suggested I reach out"). Keep email body concise (150-250 words maximum), focus on the recipient's interests rather than your agenda, and make it easy to respond with a simple yes/no or short answer question. Include personalization variables such as [First Name], [Company], [Last Interaction Date], [Shared Interest/Project], [Mutual Connection] that must be filled in for each message. Create usage guidelines that specify which template to use in which scenario, how much to customize beyond the template, optimal timing for sending, and appropriate follow-up sequences. Test new templates with a small sample of each connection category, measure results, gather any direct feedback, and refine based on data. Organize final templates in an easily accessible library with clear labeling and instructions for use.

active_tasks.title: Write About Employee Schedule Changes
steps: Gather information about all pending schedule changes
Identify affected employees and their current schedules
Determine reasons for schedule changes
Calculate effective dates for changes
Draft clear communication about changes for each employee
Include all necessary details: old schedule, new schedule, effective date, reason
Review organizational policies on schedule change notifications
Prepare documentation for HR/administrative records
Create updated schedule charts or calendars
Send individual notifications to affected employees
Update centralized schedule database or calendar
Communicate changes to relevant team members
Address questions or concerns from affected employees
Confirm receipt and understanding from all parties
resources: HR policies on scheduling and notifications
active_tasks.instructions: Start by compiling a comprehensive list of all approved schedule changes including employee name, current schedule, new schedule, effective date, and reason for change. Verify that all changes have been properly approved through the appropriate channels (manager approval, HR review, employee agreement). For each employee affected by a schedule change, prepare a personalized written notification that includes: acknowledgment of their schedule change request or explanation of business-driven change, clear statement of current schedule with specific days and times, detailed new schedule with specific days and times, exact effective date when new schedule begins, reason for the change (employee request, business needs, project requirements, etc.), any impact on compensation or benefits if applicable, next steps or actions required from the employee, and contact information for questions. Ensure your communication tone is professional, clear, and empathetic, especially for business-driven changes that may not align with employee preferences. Draft messages in a consistent format for easy reading and comprehension. For schedule reductions or unfavorable changes, include supportive language and information about any available options or resources. Create or update visual schedule representations such as shift calendars, coverage charts, or team schedules showing the new arrangements. Before sending notifications, verify all information is accurate including dates, times, and names. Send individual notifications via appropriate channels (email, formal letter, or in-person meeting depending on significance of change and company culture). Document all communications in employee files for HR records and future reference. Update all centralized scheduling systems including shared calendars, time-tracking software, shift management tools, and any public-facing schedules. Notify managers, team leads, and colleagues who work closely with affected employees so they're aware of the changes. Be prepared to answer questions about the changes including clarifications on details, addressing concerns about impact, explaining the decision-making process, and discussing any flexibility or alternatives available. Follow up with each affected employee to confirm they understand their new schedule and have no outstanding questions. Set calendar reminders for the effective dates of changes to verify smooth transitions.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Gather information about all pending schedule changes
Identify affected employees and their current schedules
Determine reasons for schedule changes
Calculate effective dates for changes
Draft clear communication about changes for each employee
Include all necessary details: old schedule, new schedule, effective date, reason
Review organizational policies on schedule change notifications
Prepare documentation for HR/administrative records
Create updated schedule charts or calendars
Send individual notifications to affected employees
Update centralized schedule database or calendar
Communicate changes to relevant team members
Address questions or concerns from affected employees
Confirm receipt and understanding from all parties

**Resources:**
- Current employee schedule master document
- Schedule change request forms
- HR policies on scheduling and notifications
- Employee handbook scheduling section
- Shared team calendar
- Communication templates for schedule changes

**Instructions:**
Start by compiling a comprehensive list of all approved schedule changes including employee name, current schedule, new schedule, effective date, and reason for change. Verify that all changes have been properly approved through the appropriate channels (manager approval, HR review, employee agreement). For each employee affected by a schedule change, prepare a personalized written notification that includes: acknowledgment of their schedule change request or explanation of business-driven change, clear statement of current schedule with specific days and times, detailed new schedule with specific days and times, exact effective date when new schedule begins, reason for the change (employee request, business needs, project requirements, etc.), any impact on compensation or benefits if applicable, next steps or actions required from the employee, and contact information for questions. Ensure your communication tone is professional, clear, and empathetic, especially for business-driven changes that may not align with employee preferences. Draft messages in a consistent format for easy reading and comprehension. For schedule reductions or unfavorable changes, include supportive language and information about any available options or resources. Create or update visual schedule representations such as shift calendars, coverage charts, or team schedules showing the new arrangements. Before sending notifications, verify all information is accurate including dates, times, and names. Send individual notifications via appropriate channels (email, formal letter, or in-person meeting depending on significance of change and company culture). Document all communications in employee files for HR records and future reference. Update all centralized scheduling systems including shared calendars, time-tracking software, shift management tools, and any public-facing schedules. Notify managers, team leads, and colleagues who work closely with affected employees so they're aware of the changes. Be prepared to answer questions about the changes including clarifications on details, addressing concerns about impact, explaining the decision-making process, and discussing any flexibility or alternatives available. Follow up with each affected employee to confirm they understand their new schedule and have no outstanding questions. Set calendar reminders for the effective dates of changes to verify smooth transitions.

active_tasks.title: Issue New Job Sites Lines
steps: Review current job site postings and active listings
Identify which positions need new or updated job posting lines
Gather requirements and specifications for each position
Research effective job posting language and keywords for each role
Draft compelling job titles that attract qualified candidates
Write clear, concise job description lines/bullet points
Include key responsibilities, qualifications, and benefits
Optimize language for searchability and applicant tracking systems (ATS)
Ensure compliance with employment regulations and non-discriminatory language
Review and refine all job posting content
Format job lines according to each platform's requirements
Get necessary approvals from hiring managers or HR
Post to designated job sites and platforms
Track posting performance and adjust as needed
resources: Job site platform accounts (LinkedIn Jobs, Indeed, Glassdoor, etc.)
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by identifying all open positions that need job site postings or updates to existing postings. For each position, gather complete information including job title, department, reporting structure, primary responsibilities, required qualifications, preferred qualifications, compensation range, benefits package, work location/remote options, and employment type (full-time, part-time, contract). Research current market standards for similar positions to ensure your job titles and descriptions are competitive and attractive. Look at successful postings from competitors and industry leaders for inspiration on structure and language. Draft attention-grabbing job titles that are both accurate and searchable - avoid internal jargon or overly creative titles that candidates won't search for. Create compelling opening lines that immediately communicate the role's value proposition and what makes this opportunity special. Write 5-7 concise bullet points for key responsibilities using action verbs and specific outcomes rather than vague duties (e.g., "Develop and execute social media strategy resulting in 50% engagement increase" rather than "Manage social media"). List must-have qualifications separately from nice-to-have qualifications to avoid deterring qualified candidates who might not meet every preferred criterion. Include information about company culture, growth opportunities, and unique benefits that differentiate your organization from competitors. Optimize content for applicant tracking systems (ATS) by incorporating relevant keywords naturally throughout the posting, using standard section headers, avoiding images or graphics with text, and using common job titles that candidates search for. Ensure all language is inclusive, non-discriminatory, and compliant with employment regulations (avoid age implications, gender-specific pronouns unless relevant to role, unnecessary physical requirements, etc.). Format job posting lines according to each platform's specific requirements - some sites have character limits, required fields, or formatting restrictions. Create multiple versions if posting across different platforms with varying requirements. Submit drafts to hiring managers and HR for review and approval, incorporating feedback and making necessary revisions. Once approved, post to all designated job sites including general platforms (Indeed, LinkedIn, Glassdoor), industry-specific job boards, company career page, and any relevant professional networks or communities. Track key metrics for each posting including views, applications, application quality, and source effectiveness. Be prepared to adjust posting language, titles, or platforms based on performance data to improve candidate quality and quantity. Set up alerts or tracking systems to monitor applications and ensure timely response to candidates.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Review current job site postings and active listings
Identify which positions need new or updated job posting lines
Gather requirements and specifications for each position
Research effective job posting language and keywords for each role
Draft compelling job titles that attract qualified candidates
Write clear, concise job description lines/bullet points
Include key responsibilities, qualifications, and benefits
Optimize language for searchability and applicant tracking systems (ATS)
Ensure compliance with employment regulations and non-discriminatory language
Review and refine all job posting content
Format job lines according to each platform's requirements
Get necessary approvals from hiring managers or HR
Post to designated job sites and platforms
Track posting performance and adjust as needed

**Resources:**
- Job site platform accounts (LinkedIn Jobs, Indeed, Glassdoor, etc.)
- Current job description repository
- ATS keyword optimization guides
- Employment law compliance checklist
- Competitive job posting examples
- Brand guidelines for job postings
- Hiring manager contact list

**Instructions:**
Begin by identifying all open positions that need job site postings or updates to existing postings. For each position, gather complete information including job title, department, reporting structure, primary responsibilities, required qualifications, preferred qualifications, compensation range, benefits package, work location/remote options, and employment type (full-time, part-time, contract). Look at successful postings from competitors and industry leaders for inspiration on structure and language. Draft attention-grabbing job titles that are both accurate and searchable - avoid internal jargon or overly creative titles that candidates won't search for. Create compelling opening lines that immediately communicate the role's value proposition and what makes this opportunity special. Write 5-7 concise bullet points for key responsibilities using action verbs and specific outcomes rather than vague duties (e.g., "Develop and execute social media strategy resulting in 50% engagement increase" rather than "Manage social media"). List must-have qualifications separately from nice-to-have qualifications to avoid deterring qualified candidates who might not meet every preferred criterion. Include information about company culture, growth opportunities, and unique benefits that differentiate your organization from competitors. Optimize content for applicant tracking systems (ATS) by incorporating relevant keywords naturally throughout the posting, using standard section headers, avoiding images or graphics with text, and using common job titles that candidates search for. Ensure all language is inclusive, non-discriminatory, and compliant with employment regulations (avoid age implications, gender-specific pronouns unless relevant to role, unnecessary physical requirements, etc.). Format job posting lines according to each platform's specific requirements - some sites have character limits, required fields, or formatting restrictions. Create multiple versions if posting across different platforms with varying requirements. Be prepared to adjust posting language, titles, or platforms based on performance data to improve candidate quality and quantity. active_tasks.title: Add Comments in Manager Streams Tracking Table
steps: Access the manager streams tracking table/spreadsheet
Review recent manager streams and broadcasts
Watch or review recorded sessions for each manager
Evaluate manager performance across multiple dimensions
Assess content quality, delivery, and engagement techniques
Note specific strengths and areas for improvement
Document technical issues or production quality concerns
Analyze student/audience engagement and participation metrics
Identify best practices and successful approaches
Draft detailed, constructive comments for each manager
Include specific examples with timestamps when relevant
Add actionable recommendations for improvement
Note any training needs or support requirements
Record positive highlights and achievements
Update the tracking table with comprehensive comments
Ensure comments are professional, balanced, and helpful
Share feedback with managers individually if required
Track progress and improvements over time
resources: Training resources and best practice guides
active_tasks.instructions: Begin by accessing the centralized manager streams tracking table where all manager broadcast activities are logged. This table should include columns for manager name, stream date/time, topic covered, attendance numbers, engagement metrics, and your detailed comments section. Review the table to identify which manager streams need comment updates, prioritizing recent streams from the past week that haven't been documented yet. For each manager stream that needs review, watch the recorded session (if available) or gather information from live notes, attendance records, and engagement metrics. Create a standardized evaluation framework that assesses multiple dimensions of manager performance including: content quality and accuracy, presentation skills and delivery style, technical proficiency with streaming tools, ability to engage and interact with audience, time management and pacing, handling of questions and discussions, preparation and organization, visual aids and materials quality, energy and enthusiasm level, clarity of explanations, and professional demeanor. As you watch each stream, take detailed notes organized by these categories. Note specific timestamps for particularly strong moments or areas needing improvement (e.g., "Excellent explanation of concept at 15:30" or "Audio quality issues between 22:00-25:00"). Evaluate student/participant engagement by reviewing chat activity, questions asked, attendance duration, and any post-stream feedback or survey results. Identify patterns such as when audience engagement peaks or drops, which topics generate most interaction, and how effectively the manager responds to questions. Document technical issues comprehensively including audio/video quality problems, connectivity issues, screen sharing difficulties, platform glitches, or any technical interruptions that affected the stream quality. Note whether these were manager errors or system issues beyond their control. Recognize and document successful techniques and best practices demonstrated by each manager. These might include effective icebreakers, engaging teaching methods, creative use of polls or interactive features, excellent storytelling, real-world examples that resonate with audience, or innovative approaches to complex topics. Draft comments that are specific, constructive, and balanced. Avoid vague statements like "good job" or "needs improvement." Instead write specific observations such as: "Strong opening that immediately captured attention by relating topic to current industry trends. Consider adding more visual examples when explaining technical concepts as audience engagement dropped slightly during the theoretical section (35:00-42:00). Excellent handling of the challenging question at 1:05:00 - turned it into a great learning moment for everyone." Structure your comments to include: opening positive observation, specific areas of strength with examples, constructive suggestions for improvement with actionable steps, technical or logistical notes, overall assessment, and any support or resources that might help the manager improve. Maintain a professional, supportive tone even when addressing significant concerns. Frame feedback as opportunities for growth rather than criticism. Use language like "Consider exploring..." or "An opportunity to enhance..." rather than "You failed to..." or "This was wrong." For managers showing consistent excellence, provide specific praise and consider highlighting their streams as examples for others. Document innovative approaches or particularly effective segments that could be shared as best practices with the team. For managers struggling with specific aspects, note whether this is a one-time issue or recurring pattern. Identify whether they need additional training, technical support, mentoring, or resources. Be specific about support recommendations such as "Would benefit from training on interactive polling features" or "Might need upgraded microphone equipment for better audio quality." Ensure all comments are entered in the appropriate cells of the tracking table with consistent formatting. If the table has character limits, write full detailed comments in a separate document and include key summary points in the table with a reference to the full feedback document. Include quantitative data where available to support your qualitative observations: attendance numbers, average viewing duration, engagement rate (comments/questions per attendee), satisfaction scores if surveys were conducted, and comparison to previous streams to show improvement trends. Tag or flag streams that require immediate attention or follow-up action, such as urgent technical issues that need resolution, content concerns that need correction, or exceptional performance that should be recognized formally. If your organization has a formal feedback schedule, coordinate your comment additions with one-on-one feedback sessions with managers. Share your documented observations during these meetings, allowing for discussion and collaborative development of improvement plans. Maintain historical tracking of comments over time to identify patterns, track improvement trajectories, and provide evidence for performance evaluations. Regular review of past comments helps ensure feedback is having desired impact and managers are progressing. Set up a regular cadence for reviewing and commenting on manager streams - for example, all streams from the previous week should have detailed comments added by Monday of the following week. Consistency ensures timely feedback when experiences are still fresh. Consider creating a rating or scoring system alongside detailed comments to allow for quick visual assessment of manager performance trends over time. This could include numerical ratings for key categories (1-5 scale) plus your detailed written comments. Collaborate with other team members who may have observed the same streams to gather multiple perspectives before finalizing comments. Different observers may notice different strengths or concerns, creating more comprehensive feedback. Before finalizing all comments, review for tone and clarity. Ensure feedback is professional, constructive, specific, actionable, balanced (noting both strengths and growth areas), and free from personal bias or subjective judgments unrelated to performance. After adding comments to the tracking table, follow up with individual managers as appropriate based on your organization's feedback protocols. Some comments may be for record-keeping only, while significant concerns or exceptional performance may warrant direct conversation. Document any follow-up actions, training scheduled, or improvement plans in the tracking table alongside your comments to provide complete record of manager development journey.
active_tasks.content:
**Steps:**
Access the manager streams tracking table/spreadsheet
Review recent manager streams and broadcasts
Watch or review recorded sessions for each manager
Evaluate manager performance across multiple dimensions
Assess content quality, delivery, and engagement techniques
Note specific strengths and areas for improvement
Document technical issues or production quality concerns
Analyze student/audience engagement and participation metrics
Identify best practices and successful approaches
Draft detailed, constructive comments for each manager
Include specific examples with timestamps when relevant
Add actionable recommendations for improvement
Note any training needs or support requirements
Record positive highlights and achievements
Update the tracking table with comprehensive comments
Ensure comments are professional, balanced, and helpful
Share feedback with managers individually if required
Track progress and improvements over time

**Resources:**
- Manager streams tracking spreadsheet/table
- Stream recording platform access
- Performance evaluation criteria and rubrics
- Previous feedback and comment history
- Training resources and best practice guides
- Quality standards documentation
- Manager contact information
- Feedback delivery guidelines

Regular review of past comments helps ensure feedback is having desired impact and managers are progressing. Consistency ensures timely feedback when experiences are still fresh. Different observers may notice different strengths or concerns, creating more comprehensive feedback. Before finalizing all comments, review for tone and clarity. Ensure feedback is professional, constructive, specific, actionable, balanced (noting both strengths and growth areas), and free from personal bias or subjective judgments unrelated to performance. After adding comments to the tracking table, follow up with individual managers as appropriate based on your organization's feedback protocols. Some comments may be for record-keeping only, while significant concerns or exceptional performance may warrant direct conversation. Document any follow-up actions, training scheduled, or improvement plans in the tracking table alongside your comments to provide complete record of manager development journey.

active_tasks.instructions:
Detailed instructions for execution...
Review their profile to gather context (company, role, recent activity)
Use approved messaging templates as a baseline, but personalize each message
Send message through LinkedIn (do NOT use automation tools)
Update CRM

B. Update CRM & create new company cards
 
 STEPS & INSTRUCTIONS 
- Create new company cards for any leads identified using the job sites spreadsheet but not yet added:
- Use SalesQL to gather comprehensive data (company size, industry, contact info)
- Ensure all required fields are completed accurately
Cross-reference LinkedIn profile with company website for accuracy
- Review and clean up any duplicate or incomplete entries Target: All active leads updated, 15-20 new company cards created

C. Re-engage Old Leads 

STEPS & INSTRUCTIONS 
- In LinkedIn, filter connections by date (Dec 2024 - Feb 2025) 
- Identify connections who have not been messaged recently, did not respond to initial outreach or showed initial interest but conversation stalled
- For each old connection:
Review previous conversation history to understand context
- Personalize and send re-engagement messages

### Resources and Links: 
Linkedin, message templates, CRM, Job sites spreadsheet, salesQL

 Task 2  - MEDIUM PRIORITY
2. Act on all corrections given by Team leads

A. Review All Feedback from Team Leads

STEPS & INSTRUCTIONS 
- Create a checklist of all corrections and action items:
LinkedIn safety measures
Messaging best practices
Account management protocols
Tool configuration requirements
- Prioritize corrections based on urgency and impact
- Implement LinkedIn Safety Protocols
 - Send follow up messages to missed leads
- Configure Google Profiles Properly
- For each lead account, verify separate Google Chrome profile exists.
- In each profile:
Install required extensions (SalesQL, any other approved tools)
Sign into correct LinkedIn account
Verify all extensions are activated and functioning
Bookmark frequently used tools and CRM
- Test each profile by performing a sample task (search, message, data lookup) Step 4: Document profile names and which LinkedIn account each manages

- Verify Workflow Alignment 
- Document current daily workflow step-by-step 
- Compare against team lead guidance 
- Identify any gaps or deviations
- Adjust workflow to match company standards 
- Share updated workflow with team lead for confirmation 


### Resources and Links: 
google chrome, message templates, LinkedIn 

LOW PRIORITY


3. Submit end of day report
### Steps:
- Review all entries in daily.md 
- Organize report into company standard format
- Proofread for clarity, accuracy, and completeness 
- Submit  all reports through designated channels.




### Resources and Links:
CRM, Claude, ChatGPT, google forms, VS Code

Detailed instructions for execution...

active_tasks.title: Complete Final Sheet Cleanup for Frank
steps: [x] Open Frank's project spreadsheet
[x] Review all archives for duplicates
[x] Remove all repeating archive entries
[x] Verify each archive is unique
[x] Test all formulas for accuracy
[x] Confirm all formulas are working correctly
[x] Do comprehensive final quality check
active_tasks.instructions:
Complete the absolute final cleanup of the sheet. Focus on removing ALL repeating archives to ensure every entry is unique. Verify every single formula is working correctly. This is the foundation for the pricing work.

**Success Criteria**:
- Zero duplicate archives
- 100% unique entries
- All formulas working perfectly
- Sheet ready for enhancement

**Status**:  COMPLETED - All archives cleaned, no repeating entries, all formulas working

active_tasks.title: Call with Frank - Implement Pricing Structure
steps: [x] Join call with Frank at scheduled time
[x] Discuss pricing structure requirements
[x] Create "Price per minute" column
[x] Create "Price per still" column
[x] Create "Total price" column
[x] Set up formulas for pricing calculations
[x] Test pricing columns with Frank
[x] Verify all pricing data is accurate
active_tasks.instructions:
Work collaboratively with Frank during the call to add the pricing structure. Create three new columns and ensure they integrate properly with the existing data. Test thoroughly during the call.

**Pricing Columns**:
- Price per minute
- Price per still
- Total price

**Success Criteria**: All three pricing columns added and working correctly

**Status**:  COMPLETED - All pricing columns added and functional

active_tasks.title: Implement Frames-to-Seconds Formula
steps: [x] Identify the need for frames-to-seconds calculation
[x] Research the correct formula approach
[x] Use ChatGPT to find the optimal formula
[x] Test the formula with sample data
[x] Implement the formula in the spreadsheet
[x] Verify formula works perfectly
[x] Document the formula for future reference
active_tasks.instructions:
Find and implement a formula that accurately converts frames to seconds. Use ChatGPT to help identify the correct formula approach. Test thoroughly to ensure accuracy across different frame rates.

**Formula Requirements**:
- Accurate frame to seconds conversion
- Works with various frame rates
- Easy to understand and maintain

**Status**:  COMPLETED - Formula found via ChatGPT and works perfectly

active_tasks.title: Remote Helpers - Massive Follow-up Campaign
steps: [x] Review complete list of old connections
[x] Prioritize connections for follow-up
[x] Draft personalized messages for different segments
[x] Send follow-up messages systematically
[x] Track all sent messages (target: 80+)
[x] Monitor for immediate responses
[x] Update tracking system
active_tasks.instructions:
Execute a large-scale follow-up campaign to old connections. Aim to send 80+ messages. Personalize where possible but maintain efficiency. Focus on re-engagement and value proposition.

**Follow-up Strategy**:
- Reference previous interactions when relevant
- Add new value or perspective
- Keep messages concise
- Include clear call-to-action
- Be persistent but professional
- Segment by engagement level

**Target**: 80+ follow-up messages sent

**Status**:  COMPLETED - 82 messages sent to old connections (exceeded target!)
